summary:
As a data scientist, my drive is to push the boundaries of digital transformation while constantly seeking to expand my knowledge. 

I am particularly interested in Agile methodology and leading projects/teams, and I am eager to develop my leadership skills. My passion is in finding solutions to complex problems while maintaining empathy. 

I always keep in mind that the pursuit of perfection can hinder progress, the adage "perfect is the enemy of good" is something that guides me in my approach

awards.title: Benchmarking Semantic Capabilities of Analogy Querying Algorithms
awards.description:
http://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-32025-0_29
Enabling semantically rich query paradigms is one of the core challenges of current information systems research. In this context, due to their importance and ubiquity in natural language, analogy queries are of particular interest. Current developments in natural language processing and machine learning resulted in some very promising algorithms relying on deep learning neural word embeddings which might contribute to finally realizing analogy queries. However, it is still quite unclear how well these algorithms work from a semantic point of view. One of the problems is that there is no clear consensus on the intended semantics of analogy queries. Furthermore, there are no suitable benchmark dataset available respecting the semantic properties of real-life analogies. Therefore, in this, paper, we discuss the challenges of benchmarking the semantics of analogy query algorithms with a special focus on neural embeddings. We also introduce the AGS analogy benchmark dataset which rectifies many weaknesses of established datasets. Finally, our experiments evaluating state-of-the-art algorithms underline the need for further research in this promising field.

projects.title: Organized Elective “Data Science” module
projects.description:
This project was designed as part of a one-week Data Science course at the Eindhoven University of Technology. 
Main goal of this project was to introduce Data Science technology to PDEng students of Software Technology, Clinical Informatics, Design and Technology of Instrumentation, and Qualified Medical Engineering.
The data for this project was provided by Jeroen Bosch Ziekenhuis (JBZ). Based on the dataset presented and the questions proposed, students were divided into four teams to tackle the problem from different perspectives. Four different approaches were defined, one per team. 
To use time in an optimum way, we defined and followed a structured group process. Each team had several brainstorming sessions to clarify the problem, discuss ideas, develop the ideas, and make a plan for the implementation.
We ended up the project/module by having a successful presentation.

projects.title: Data Science challenge week (Philips lighting)
projects.description:
The Data Science challenge week was designed by Philipse (Eindhoven) and Jheronimus academy of data science. There were seven different teams and a distinct problem for each team. At that time, I was an applicant for the PDeng Data Science program.
Our team was given clickstream data from one of the Philips website.
The objective goal of Philips was to distill the useful information from the dataset.
Our team aimed at finding user behavior patterns and visualizing it. This would help Philips to understand the behavior of users/customers. From information, Philips can improve the website interface, which will lead to higher satisfaction of customers.

contributors.headline: Digital Trasnformation & Data Scientist | Certified SAFe® 5 Practitioner | Certified SAFe® 5 Product Owner/Product Manager

projects.title: Data Engineering of  Asphalting Data (Heijmans)
projects.description:
Heijmans combines activities related to property development, residential building, non-residential building, roads, and civil engineering. 
For this case study, we have data from the process of construction of the roadway.
The construction of the roadway using asphalt pavement consists of five steps:
1) Production of the asphalt, 2) Transportation of the asphalt from the production site to the construction site, 3) Paving the asphalt using paver machines, 4) Compacting the paved road using different types of roller machines, 5) Quality check of the roadway.
Each facility involved in the five steps as described briefly above has a dedicated data acquisition unit, though the collected data are inconsistent in format; no data architecture, which makes it difficult to fit into the web-based dashboard for analysis.
Among these five, three data acquisition systems stores the data into the cloud system (a closed network of data providers) and two data acquisition systems are locally at Heijmans. 
For this project, we discussed and designed a prototype design for data architecture that can support Heijmans' goal.

contributors.headline: Digital Trasnformation & Data Scientist | Certified SAFe® 5 Practitioner | Certified SAFe® 5 Product Owner/Product Manager

projects.title: Analysis of Asphalting Process for Heijmans
projects.description:
The prime goal of the company was to find the weakened areas of the Schiphol runway by analyzing the data collected during different construction phases (Transportation, Paving, and Compaction). 
First, we created a web-based visualization tool to analyze the temperature profile of asphalt. These would help in finding weakened areas that are not paved or compacted at an optimum temperature. These weakened areas are visualized as a red bubble on the map. By clicking on the particular red bubble, it displays the temperature profile of an asphalt at each construction phase. 
Second, we created a speed profile of the different machines (Paver and Rollers). From speed profile, we found a correlation between machines’ speed and quality of the runway. We found that sometimes Paver and Rollers are not working at defined optimum speed, which could be a reason for the reduced quality of the runway.
In the last, we observed an evident correlation between environmental factors and temperature of asphalt. In the morning or rainy days, the rate of change in temperature of asphalt is high. In contrast, after the midday or sunny days, the rate of change in temperature of asphalt is low.

projects.title: TaskFlower: Competence-Based Feedback Mechanisms for Crowd Workers
projects.description:
One of the primary concerns in paid microtask crowdsourcing systems is that of quality and reliability of the results produced. In this work, we aim to improve the effectiveness of the crowdsourcing paradigm (regarding the quality of results produced, turnover time of the task) by inducing competence-based self-selection of microtasks among crowd workers. This means that workers would only work on the tasks that they believe they can complete based on their competence. To ensure that workers refrain from participating in microtasks that are beyond their competence, they first need to be aware of their limitations. By providing workers with an assessment of their competence in particular microtasks, we hypothesise that by providing competence-based feedback, workers will tend to pick tasks that are better for them. 
Here, we propose three experimental conditions: 1) control, 2) implicit, and 3) explicit. Control condition follows the normal workflow of a crowdsourcing platforms. For implicit and explicit experimental conditions, we implement two kinds of feedback mechanism systems implicit and explicit feedback. In these feedback designs, we provide different kinds of feedback to the workers. Here, we hypothesise that competence-based feedback delivered explicitly is more efficient than implicit methods of competence-based feedback.
Analysis of workers’ data shows that 70% of the task selections are affected by explicit feedback with an overall accuracy of 70.59%. Where implicit feedback affected 59.35% of the task selection with an overall accuracy of 69.89%. On the other hand, workers of control condition provide overall accuracy of 50.69% with no feedback. Workers of the explicit and implicit experimental conditions took less time to finish the tasks compared to the workers of control experimental condition.
Crowdsourcing marketplaces can significantly benefit from this, by training their workforce to progress towards higher competence and improved reputation.

profile_positions.description:
Driving Digitalization initiatives for the Global Component Planning Team: 

Product Owner of RoboComp: Collaborating with the data engineer and demand planners to define a roadmap, add new futures, manage change requests, and track progress.
Extracting data (Data-Lake) from multiple sources, such as SAP Helios, Excel, and MySQL. Transforming and analyzing data to generate goods movement reports using Python and VBA. 

Robotic Process Automation: Initiated RPA use cases for the team and worked with an external vendor (UI-Path). Saved ~2000 hours of manual work and #K Euro per year by automating two processes. 

Reporting server: Data/Driven approach to minimize workload, increase efficiency, and productivity of teams. Automated more than 40 reports for analysis.
Generating reports using various technologies, such as Excel, SAP-Analysis, VBA, Window Scheduler, and SAP Analytics Cloud.

Project Management: Led Global Forecast collection that helps the team to plan component supply using Python, Apache Airflow, excel, and MySQL. 

Other activities: Organized PowerBI and Power Automate workshop for the team, presented Digitalization initiatives during a global podcast, and was part of the interview process for recruiting a “Data Engineer” and “Digital Manufacturing Project Leader”.
